data.text: Best Travel Bag to Pack Your Bike in for an International Flight

Best travel bag to pack your Gravel bike in for an international flight? Obvious goal is to have zero damage to bike and 2nd goal is to minimize how much of the bike I have to disassemble. I‚Äôm looking for a high end/durable bag. Thanks!
Scicon hard cases.

data.text: thanks Dave

data.text: Evoc Road Bag Pro. Put additional padding/bubble wrap. GREAT bag!
data.author: Steven Bedard

data.text: Love my EVOC Pro.
data.author: Brian Stewart

data.text: Evoc Pro
data.author: Eric Vollmer

data.text: +1 on the pro. Don‚Äôt have one personally, but borrowed one recently for a trip and it was great
data.author: Greg Maino

data.text: I have an EVOC and it works well, but it requires some disassembly. I have a friend with a Scion bag and the beauty of it is that it requires no disassembly - take the wheels off and the frame locks into the stand. Easy. The knock is that it's pretty big so you'll have to see what your airline will handle and what car you take to/from the airport.
data.author: Ching-yen Chen

data.text: Bike Box Alan Tri easy fit case....minimal disassembly ...
data.author: Larry Narachi

data.text: I have been happy with my Topeak Pakgo X. Overseas flight without any damage to bag or bike. It has a built in "work stand" that comes handy when you have to assemble the bike upon arrival.
data.author: Nice Cyclist

data.text: me too!
data.author: Christine May

data.text: One thing to keep in mind is rental van availability at your destination. Most large bike bags will require a van which this year is about double that of a large car that a smaller bike bag might fit in.
data.author: Mark Studnicki

data.text: ‚ÄúTri-all-3‚Äù case if it‚Äôs still made
data.author: Robert Licho

data.text: Evoc Pro case is great because you can also use for a MTB and the low weight (sun 20 lbs) means you can fly with the bike as regular luggage through most airlines. The hard cases are great but weigh more and expect $100 additional fee both ways when flying.
data.author: David Schwartz

data.text:
Transfer case from Post Carry is the best I‚Äôve ever used. Rolls up when you arrive to fit in any car. https://postcarry.co
Post Carry Co.
postcarry.co

data.text: Hardside case. Until TSA unpacks everything, repacks it messed up, and breaks your bike. Ask me how I know ü§™
data.author: JJ DK

data.text: Following
data.author: Lee Goldberg

data.text: The question is what are you going to do with this case when you start your ride? Pack it on the bike, ship it somewhere, put it in storage somewhere ? I think this is why most people use cardboard boxes that shipped bikes come in and throw it in the trash when they get to their destination and pick up a box just before they leave from a local bike store for the flight home .
data.author: Joshua Miller

data.text: very good point
data.author: Dave Evetts

data.text: even line up a return trip box before you land.

data.text: nope, haven‚Äôt had the pleasure of a bike ride abroad. Definitely planning on it. So much to see in Idaho still

data.author: Mark Almond

data.text: The problem I had was what to do with it once I got there. Storage at a airport nope. I had mine boxed up. I‚Äôm riding for 28 days in Croatia. If it was a short trip yea EVOC
data.author: Chris Kerr

data.text: I saw one guy used 4 boxes of Saran wrap that you get in the kitchen aisle.
data.author: Joshua Miller

data.text: EVOC Pro
data.author: Duane Orth

data.text: Evoc Pro for sure! I have two and travel a lot with them.
data.author: Aaron Friedman

data.text: As a few others have mentioned. What to do with it when there. Some hotels will store for you or airports. This is useless if doing a one way trip. I prefer a bike box. It has the space for extras and really all I need to do is remove front wheel, handlebar, pedals, and saddle. There's extra space along the bottom of the box for your packs when touring, meaning carry on can be kept to a minimum. Never had an issue reaching out to bike shops in destination cities for a new box.
data.author: Georges Erhard

data.text: why get a new box at destination cities? Can‚Äôt you just use the same box again to return? I‚Äôm planning a trip in a couple weeks with my bike box that my bike was shipped in
data.author: Todd Trattner

data.text: that would mean carrying it for however long you ride for. Not exactly areo lol
data.author: Georges Erhard

data.text: ahh - if you don‚Äôt have a place to store it. Got it. I have a place to store it
data.author: Todd Trattner

data.text: Free bike box & packaging material from a bike shop
data.author: Bobby Ruple

data.text: I use an Orucase B2-MTB. Very clever design. Gives you a lot more flexibility with respect to rental cars than a hard case.
data.author: Mark Rosenberg

data.text: Thule Roundtrip MTB. My Hakka fits perfectly, best part is a portable workstand is part of the design.
